investigation. Contrary to similar quasiparticles found in frus- trated lattices [22] or quantum skyrmions embedded in a classical magnet [24], we show that the skyrmion lattice phase reported here emerges from entangled :formula: pairs, which bear witness to a genuine quantum mechanical origin without classical analog, a feature that may pave the way toward a microscopic description of skyrmion qubits used for realizing quantum logic elements based on nanoscale devices [25].
II. MODEL
We study the zero-temperature phase diagram of a quantum spin-1/2 Heisenberg model with DMI and external magnetic field. The Hamiltonian reads:
:formula: (1)
where :formula: with Pauli matrices :formula: for :formula: denotes a :formula: operator at position :formula: :formula: is the ferro- magnetic exchange coupling strength, :formula: is the DMI vector, and :formula: denotes the applied magnetic field along the z axis. The notation :formula: implies a sum over all pairs of nearest-neighbor lattice sites. In Sec. VI, we will also consider the impact of a uniaxial magnetic anisotropy with strength :formula:
:formula: (2)
We solve the above Hamiltonian numerically by means of matrix product state (MPS) simulations on different two-dimensional (2D) Bravais lattices with open boundary conditions consisting of lattice sites :formula: spanned by basis vectors :formula: with :formula: For details on the implemen- tation and on the 2D-1D mapping required for using MPS, we refer to the Appendix and Ref. We apply the external magnetic field :formula: parallel to the lattice plane normal :formula: Without loss of generality, we as- sume negative values :formula: such that field-polarized spins are eigenstates of :formula: with eigenvalue :formula: and therefore align with the plane normal. For convenience, we will express interatomic distances in units of the lattice constants :formula: and energies in units of :formula: with :formula: 1.

Arrows depict the direction and size of the magnetization components mx/yr perpendicular to the external field. We study different triangular (a)-(1) and square (m)-(r) systems with regular boundaries (odd rows) and circular boundaries (even rows). The parameters used are :formula: and :formula: with a varying external field :formula: (first column), :formula: (second column) and :formula: (third column). We find quantum skyrmions for system sizes larger than a critical diameter :formula: irrespective of the lattice symmetries and boundary conditions.
The Hamiltonian (1) may be seen as the quantum coun- terpart of typical classical spin models which give rise to magnetic skyrmions [1-4]. In this work, we discuss the emer- gence of quantum skyrmions and quantum skyrmion lattices in two-dimensional triangular and square lattices at zero tem- perature and with different open boundary shapes (see Fig. 2).
III. INDIVIDUAL QUANTUM SKYRMIONS
For small system diameters :formula: the exact eigenvalues and eigenvectors of the full Hamiltonian can be computed nu- merically, for instance by the Lanczos or Arnoldi algorithms, and we first cross-checked our own ED codes by reproducing the results of Ref. [23]. To ensure the correctness of our find- ings, we further compared expectation values computed from the MPS obtained by DMRG with ED results for all system sizes amenable for ED and found quantitative agreement up to
043113-2
QUANTUM SKYRMION LATTICES IN HEISENBERG ...
a self-imposed accuracy :formula: We thereby checked that finite-size ground states of the :formula: Hamiltonian can be approxi- mated faithfully with MPS (for more details, see Appendix A and [26]). In fact, the reliability of DMRG for 2D spin-1/2 quantum Heisenberg models has already been demonstrated in numerous works, with a strong bias toward frustrated antifer- romagnets and spin liquids, which are prime examples of the most demanding systems to simulate numerically due to the presence of topological order and long-range entanglement [27-57]. In this work, we focus on the computationally less demanding scenario of magnetically ordered phases hosting skyrmions and field-polarized (FP) states in the ferromagnetic regime :formula:
Beyond a critical system diameter of :formula: we find val- :formula: and :formula: for which the ground state of the Hamiltonian :formula: hosts skyrmion-like spin textures confined in the interior (bulk) of the lattice, which we display in Fig. 2. We checked that these skyrmion wave functions correspond to approxi- mate eigenstates of the Hamiltonian by computing the energy variance :formula: and performed a linear extrapolation toward results without numerical errors (see Appendix A for a discussion).
We compute the components of the spin magnetization, which are local expectation values :formula: Since :formula: is parallel to the external field, we call this magnetization com- ponent the polarization. For :formula: the local spin profiles yield magnetization textures similar to those obtained for classical skyrmion configurations of the Néel :formula: type: the central spin is polarized opposite to the applied magnetic field, and the spins wind radially from the center toward the periphery. In Fig. 2, we depict the polarization along the field :formula: using a color scale and the in-plane magnetization :formula: by arrows. More detailed radial and an- gular distributions of panel Fig. 2(e) are depicted in Fig. 3. In Fig. 4, we show that the average polarization :formula: as a function of the external field, yields three disconnected regions uniquely associated with the three phases of Eq. (1).
We estimate the size of an individual quantum skyrmion as the number of lattice sites over which the polarization changes its orientation once and the components orthogonal to the external field vanish. The radius can then be read out from Figs. 2 and 3 and results in :formula: for :formula: and :formula: 0. These quantum skyrmion (SK) ground states occur not only for the fine-tuned parameters presented in Fig. 2 but in a wide range of intermediate values of the magnetic field. Furthermore, the emergence of individual skyrmions for small lattices is largely independent of the lattice geometry. While the effect of boundaries cannot be neglected for the small systems considered here, we verified that the size of an individual skyrmion is neither affected by the boundary conditions (see Fig. 2) nor the system diameter (see Fig. 8).
As we show in Fig. 2, for small magnetic fields, the sys- tem's ground state is a helical spin spiral (HS) state. This is characterized by a degenerate ground state, in which each pos- sible ground state features oscillations of the magnetization along a symmetry axis of the lattice. The large ground-state degeneracy makes the spin spiral phase notoriously difficult to simulate for tensor network states. In contrast, for large mag- netic fields, the system reaches a ferromagnetic state, where all spins are polarized parallel to the external magnetic field. The bulk of the field-polarized ferromagnet is devoid of entan-

ANDREAS HALLER et al.
IV. ENTANGLEMENT
To probe whether the spins of a skyrmion are entangled, a genuine quantum feature of many-body systems, we compute the entanglement entropy of a suitable bipartition of the sys- tem. The latter is defined as :formula: which can be understood as the von Neumann entropy of the reduced density matrix :formula: obtained by splitting the set of lattice sites :formula: into two disjoint sets :formula: and :formula: and performing the partial trace over subsystem :formula: For our purposes, it is sufficient to fix :formula: and :formula: as two patches that are symmetric about the central site (see Appendix B). We denote the entropy associated with this symmetric center-site partition choice as :formula: which is plotted in color in Fig. 4 and Fig. 9, panels (c) and (d).
MPS are constructed to target states of small entropy by truncating the reduced density matrix to a dimension :formula: which yields an upper bound for the entangle- ment entropy of an MPS state, :formula: a quantity on the order of :formula: for typical simulations. The bulk of FP states can be approximated by product states of :formula: particles aligned to the axis of the magnetic field, and for those states, one finds :formula: up to small finite-size corrections. In contrast, for systems hosting a single quantum skyrmion, we obtain val- ues for the entanglement entropy in the range :formula: which demonstrates the presence of significant entanglement in the :formula: quantum skyrmion and indicates that they can- not be expressed as a classical product state. Finally, in the HS phase, we find the strongest entanglement :formula: While we focus mainly on skyrmions with ferromagnetic exchange interaction :formula: we find strong signatures of skyrmions and skyrmion lattices for antiferromagnetic exchange :formula: 0) as well. However, this phase differs from the ferromag- netic skyrmions and skyrmion lattices, most apparently in the entanglement, which is significantly larger. We postpone a detailed investigation of quantum skyrmions and skyrmion lattices for antiferromagnetic exchange couplings to future work.
The von Neumann entropy targets quantum correlations between a bipartition of the system but does not provide local information about the entanglement between individual spin- :formula: pairs. To access the spatial distribution of entanglement, it is therefore more convenient to calculate the concurrence :formula: defined for two lattice sites at positions :formula: and :formula: For a generic state it can be expressed through the root of the spectrum of the non-Hermitian matrix :formula: where :formula: is the reduced density matrix of the two sites :formula: and :formula: and :formula: is a rotation of this reduced density matrix. The concurrence is constructed from the square roots :formula: (ordered in decreasing order) of the eigenvalues of :formula:
:formula: (4)
It is related to the entanglement of formation: for separable states :formula: vanishes, and it increases monotonically toward the limit :formula: for two maximally entangled spin-1/2's [58]. Using the concurrence, we obtain the space-resolved entan- glement distribution between spin pairs in the different phases and present its qualitative distribution by green links in Fig. 5. For a more quantitative analysis, we differentiate between

For HS states, we find the largest concurrences up to :formula: 0.16. Therefore, we use :formula: as a measure of reference to quantify the entanglement of the remaining ordered states. For the :formula: states (large magnetic field), we find almost vanishing entanglement in the bulk, indicating that the bulk spins are separable. Small nonzero values of :formula: occur at the boundary due to the finite system size and strong DMI. Fi- nally, for the quantum SK states (intermediate magnetic field), we find that the spins inside the skyrmion quasiparticle are only weakly entangled, but we find concurrences :formula: at the outer rim spins of the skyrmion, signaling significant en- tanglement of the quantum skyrmion with the field-polarized environment. Interestingly, both the helical state and quantum skyrmion show long-range concurrences between distant spin pairs beyond next-to-nearest neighbors.

We find that HS and SK states feature entangled spin pairs beyond next-nearest neighbors, whereas FP states show only minute entanglement at the system boundaries with vanishing entanglement in the bulk.

The HS state in Fig. 7(a) is characterized by a superposition of spin spirals with wave vectors :formula: resulting in six pronounced Bragg peaks :formula: We observe in the SK phase a superposition of the two extreme limits: In particular, we find a Bragg peak at :formula: together with an off-diagonal Bragg "ring" caused by the radial polarization winding of the skyrmion [see Fig. 7(b)]. Hence, the predicted quantum skyrmion profile yields a distinct signature in the measurable neutron scattering cross section and allows a determination of its size. quantum spin-1/2 Heisenberg models. We expect MPS to reliably capture the physics of the quantum skyrmion lattice phase because the external field polarizes the environment, and the resulting states carry no entanglement in the paramag- netic regions, but localized entanglement around the domain wall of the skyrmion.
We typically start with random MPS initial states of bond dimensions up to :formula: followed by sequential vari- ational optimizations ("sweeping") of two adjacent tensors (two-site DMRG). The two-site DMRG allows us to estimate the truncation error :formula: which we use in Fig. 10 to extrapolate toward results without numerical errors. To ensure that we display converged results only, we carefully monitor local spin expectation values and stop the simulation if changes in the observables become smaller than :formula: Since we use DMRG in two spatial dimensions, convergence to a spin spiral state may require many sweeps, on the order of 100-1000. The quality of the approximate ground state with energy :formula: can be estimated by the energy variance
:formula: (A2)
By construction, :formula: for exact eigenstates of the Hamilto- nian. Since MPS approximates the wave function with a finite bond dimension :formula: we have :formula: and :formula: 0 in general. Similarly, :formula: converges to the true eigenstate energy. To estimate the numerical error of our approximate wave functions, we perform linear extrapolations of the energy scaled against the truncation error [28] and the energy variance [43]. The outcomes of this extrapolation are presented in Fig. 10 and Table II. We want to stress that the MPS approximations corresponding to skyrmion and
field-polarized states easily reach convergence within a few dozen sweeps and follow the expected linear trend in the approximation errors :formula: and :formula: [26].
Changes in the local spin expectation values beyond :formula: 128 are invisible to the naked eye when displayed on the scales used in the main text such that a detailed error extrapolation is not needed. A word of caution is due in the case of helical spin spiral states: as we already explained in the main text, these states are difficult to simulate using MPS due to the large degeneracy of the ground-state manifold. This leads to some issues in reaching convergence (up to 1000 sweeps are needed) which for too small bond dimensions may even cause DMRG to get stuck in local energy minima corresponding to excited eigenstates. In the helical phase and for large lattices, MPS is thus not always reliably converging to approximations of the global ground state but converges under some circum- stances to low-lying excited states with less entanglement.
APPENDIX B: MAPPING FROM 2D TO 1D
Before we can apply DMRG to the system at hand, the 2D lattice must be mapped to a 1D chain. The map from a 2D lattice to a 1D chain can be performed by a sequential numbering of the lattice nodes with major ordering along an arbitrary axis (zigzag order). We choose the major axis to be :formula: This can be achieved by :formula: where :formula: is an auxiliary function that encodes the lattice open boundary conditions and :formula:
As a result, the lattice Hamiltonian :formula: :formula: a chain Hamiltonian :formula: :formula: To simplify the remaining discussion, we now assume square or rhomboid boundary conditions (see Fig. 12), and :formula: such that :formula: On-site contributions remain local, nearest-neighbor interactions along the major axis remain short ranged, but the interactions along the :formula: axis now have an extended range :formula: This results in a growth of the dimension of the Hamiltonian matrix product operator :formula: To obtain reasonable computation times for large
FIG. 11. The three distinct ground states of Eq. (1) (spin spiral, skyrmion, field-polarized) obtained by two different :formula: mapping strategies: zigzag (top row) vs. spiral (bottom row). The polarization is depicted by colors and arrows, and the von Neumann entropy is encoded by links in gray scale. Whereas the von Neumann entropy is rather small and homogeneously distributed for the zigzag order, it appears not only larger but also inhomogeneous for the spiral ordered 1D chain.

ANDREAS HALLER et al.
IV. ENTANGLEMENT
To probe whether the spins of a skyrmion are entangled, a
genuine quantum feature of many-body systems, we compute
the entanglement entropy of a suitable bipartition of the sys-
tem. The latter is defined as :formula: which can
be understood as the von Neumann entropy of the reduced
density matrix :formula: obtained by splitting the set of
lattice sites :formula: into two disjoint sets :formula: and :formula: and performing
the partial trace over subsystem :formula: For our purposes, it is
sufficient to fix :formula: and :formula: as two patches that are symmetric
about the central site (see Appendix B). We denote the entropy
associated with this symmetric center-site partition choice as
:formula: which is plotted in color in Fig. 4 and Fig. 9, panels (c)
and (d).
MPS are constructed to target states of small entropy
by truncating the reduced density matrix to a dimension
:formula: which yields an upper bound for the entangle-
ment entropy of an MPS state, :formula: a quantity on the
order of :formula: for typical simulations. The bulk of FP states
can be approximated by product states of :formula: particles
aligned to the axis of the magnetic field, and for those states,
one finds :formula: up to small finite-size corrections. In contrast,
for systems hosting a single quantum skyrmion, we obtain val-
ues for the entanglement entropy in the range :formula:
which demonstrates the presence of significant entanglement
in the :formula: quantum skyrmion and indicates that they can-
not be expressed as a classical product state. Finally, in the HS
phase, we find the strongest entanglement :formula: While
we focus mainly on skyrmions with ferromagnetic exchange
interaction :formula: we find strong signatures of skyrmions
and skyrmion lattices for antiferromagnetic exchange :formula:
0) as well. However, this phase differs from the ferromag-
netic skyrmions and skyrmion lattices, most apparently in the
entanglement, which is significantly larger. We postpone a
detailed investigation of quantum skyrmions and skyrmion
lattices for antiferromagnetic exchange couplings to future
work.
The von Neumann entropy targets quantum correlations
between a bipartition of the system but does not provide local
information about the entanglement between individual spin-
:formula: pairs. To access the spatial distribution of entanglement,
it is therefore more convenient to calculate the concurrence
:formula: defined for two lattice sites at positions :formula: and :formula:
For a generic state it can be expressed through the root of
the spectrum of the non-Hermitian matrix :formula:
where :formula: is the reduced density matrix of the
two sites :formula: and :formula: and :formula: is a
rotation of this reduced density matrix. The concurrence is
constructed from the square roots :formula: (ordered in decreasing
order) of the eigenvalues of :formula:
It is related to the entanglement of formation: for separable
states :formula: vanishes, and it increases monotonically toward the
limit :formula: for two maximally entangled spin-1/2's [58].
Using the concurrence, we obtain the space-resolved entan-
glement distribution between spin pairs in the different phases
and present its qualitative distribution by green links in Fig. 5.

For HS states, we find the largest concurrences up to :formula:
0.16. Therefore, we use :formula: as a measure of reference to
quantify the entanglement of the remaining ordered states. For
the :formula: states (large magnetic field), we find almost vanishing
entanglement in the bulk, indicating that the bulk spins are
separable. Small nonzero values of :formula: occur at the
boundary due to the finite system size and strong DMI. Fi-
nally, for the quantum SK states (intermediate magnetic field),
we find that the spins inside the skyrmion quasiparticle are
only weakly entangled, but we find concurrences :formula:
at the outer rim spins of the skyrmion, signaling significant en-
tanglement of the quantum skyrmion with the field-polarized
environment. Interestingly, both the helical state and quantum
skyrmion show long-range concurrences between distant spin
pairs beyond next-to-nearest neighbors.

quantum spin-1/2 Heisenberg models. We expect MPS to
reliably capture the physics of the quantum skyrmion lattice
phase because the external field polarizes the environment,
and the resulting states carry no entanglement in the paramag-
netic regions, but localized entanglement around the domain
wall of the skyrmion.
We typically start with random MPS initial states of bond
dimensions up to :formula: followed by sequential vari-
ational optimizations ("sweeping") of two adjacent tensors
(two-site DMRG). The two-site DMRG allows us to estimate
the truncation error :formula: which we use in Fig. 10
to extrapolate toward results without numerical errors. To
ensure that we display converged results only, we carefully
monitor local spin expectation values and stop the simulation
if changes in the observables become smaller than :formula:
Since we use DMRG in two spatial dimensions, convergence
to a spin spiral state may require many sweeps, on the order
of 100-1000. The quality of the approximate ground state
with energy :formula: can be estimated by
the energy variance
By construction, :formula: for exact eigenstates of the Hamilto-
nian. Since MPS approximates the wave function with a finite
bond dimension :formula: we have :formula: and :formula:
0 in general. Similarly, :formula: converges to the
true eigenstate energy. To estimate the numerical error of our
approximate wave functions, we perform linear extrapolations
of the energy scaled against the truncation error [28] and
the energy variance [43]. The outcomes of this extrapolation
are presented in Fig. 10 and Table II. We want to stress
that the MPS approximations corresponding to skyrmion and
field-polarized states easily reach convergence within a few
dozen sweeps and follow the expected linear trend in the
approximation errors :formula: and :formula: [26].
Changes in the local spin expectation values beyond :formula:
128 are invisible to the naked eye when displayed on the scales
used in the main text such that a detailed error extrapolation
is not needed. A word of caution is due in the case of helical
spin spiral states: as we already explained in the main text,
these states are difficult to simulate using MPS due to the
large degeneracy of the ground-state manifold. This leads to
some issues in reaching convergence (up to 1000 sweeps are
needed) which for too small bond dimensions may even cause
DMRG to get stuck in local energy minima corresponding to
excited eigenstates. In the helical phase and for large lattices,
MPS is thus not always reliably converging to approximations
of the global ground state but converges under some circum-
stances to low-lying excited states with less entanglement.
APPENDIX B: MAPPING FROM 2D TO 1D
Before we can apply DMRG to the system at hand, the
2D lattice must be mapped to a 1D chain. The map from a
2D lattice to a 1D chain can be performed by a sequential
numbering of the lattice nodes with major ordering along an
arbitrary axis (zigzag order). We choose the major axis to be

investigation. Contrary to similar quasiparticles found in frus- trated lattices [22] or quantum skyrmions embedded in a classical magnet [24], we show that the skyrmion lattice phase reported here emerges from entangled :formula: pairs, which bear witness to a genuine quantum mechanical origin without classical analog, a feature that may pave the way toward a microscopic description of skyrmion qubits used for realizing quantum logic elements based on nanoscale devices [25].
We study the zero-temperature phase diagram of a quantum spin-1/2 Heisenberg model with DMI and external magnetic field. The Hamiltonian reads:

where :formula: with Pauli matrices :formula: for :formula: denotes a :formula: operator at position :formula: :formula: is the ferro- magnetic exchange coupling strength, :formula: is the DMI vector, and :formula: denotes the applied magnetic field along the z axis. The notation :formula: implies a sum over all pairs of nearest-neighbor lattice sites. In Sec. VI, we will also consider the impact of a uniaxial magnetic anisotropy with strength :formula:

We solve the above Hamiltonian numerically by means of matrix product state (MPS) simulations on different two-dimensional (2D) Bravais lattices with open boundary conditions consisting of lattice sites :formula: spanned by basis vectors :formula: with :formula: For details on the implemen- tation and on the 2D-1D mapping required for using MPS, we refer to the Appendix and Ref. [26]. The DMI vectors read
with a positive DMI vector amplitude :formula: For triangular and square lattices, we depicted the orientation of the DMI vectors in Fig. 1.

We apply the external magnetic field :formula: parallel to the lattice plane normal :formula: Without loss of generality, we as- sume negative values :formula: such that field-polarized spins are eigenstates of :formula: with eigenvalue :formula: and therefore align with the plane normal. For convenience, we will express interatomic distances in units of the lattice constants :formula: and energies in units of :formula: with :formula: 1.

FIG. 2. Local polarization :formula: (in color) of the ground states of the three different phases as obtained by DMRG simulations of Eq. (1). Arrows depict the direction and size of the magnetization components mx/yr perpendicular to the external field. We study different triangular (a)-(1) and square (m)-(r) systems with regular boundaries (odd rows) and circular boundaries (even rows). The parameters used are :formula: and :formula: with a varying external field :formula: (first column), :formula: (second column) and :formula: (third column). We find quantum skyrmions for system sizes larger than a critical diameter :formula: irrespective of the lattice symmetries and boundary conditions.

The Hamiltonian (1) may be seen as the quantum coun- terpart of typical classical spin models which give rise to magnetic skyrmions [1-4]. In this work, we discuss the emer- gence of quantum skyrmions and quantum skyrmion lattices in two-dimensional triangular and square lattices at zero tem- perature and with different open boundary shapes (see Fig. 2).

For small system diameters :formula: the exact eigenvalues and eigenvectors of the full Hamiltonian can be computed nu- merically, for instance by the Lanczos or Arnoldi algorithms, and we first cross-checked our own ED codes by reproducing the results of Ref. [23]. To ensure the correctness of our find- ings, we further compared expectation values computed from the MPS obtained by DMRG with ED results for all system sizes amenable for ED and found quantitative agreement up to

a self-imposed accuracy :formula: We thereby checked that finite-size ground states of the :formula: Hamiltonian can be approxi- mated faithfully with MPS (for more details, see Appendix A and [26]). In fact, the reliability of DMRG for 2D spin-1/2 quantum Heisenberg models has already been demonstrated in numerous works, with a strong bias toward frustrated antifer- romagnets and spin liquids, which are prime examples of the most demanding systems to simulate numerically due to the presence of topological order and long-range entanglement [27-57]. In this work, we focus on the computationally less demanding scenario of magnetically ordered phases hosting skyrmions and field-polarized (FP) states in the ferromagnetic regime :formula:

Beyond a critical system diameter of :formula: we find val- :formula: and :formula: for which the ground state of the Hamiltonian :formula: hosts skyrmion-like spin textures confined in the interior (bulk) of the lattice, which we display in Fig. 2. We checked that these skyrmion wave functions correspond to approxi- mate eigenstates of the Hamiltonian by computing the energy variance :formula: and performed a linear extrapolation toward results without numerical errors (see Appendix A for a discussion).

We compute the components of the spin magnetization, which are local expectation values :formula: Since :formula: is parallel to the external field, we call this magnetization com- ponent the polarization. For :formula: the local spin profiles yield magnetization textures similar to those obtained for classical skyrmion configurations of the Néel :formula: type: the central spin is polarized opposite to the applied magnetic field, and the spins wind radially from the center toward the periphery. In Fig. 2, we depict the polarization along the field :formula: using a color scale and the in-plane magnetization :formula: by arrows. More detailed radial and an- gular distributions of panel Fig. 2(e) are depicted in Fig. 3. In Fig. 4, we show that the average polarization :formula: as a function of the external field, yields three disconnected regions uniquely associated with the three phases of Eq. (1).

We estimate the size of an individual quantum skyrmion as the number of lattice sites over which the polarization changes its orientation once and the components orthogonal to the external field vanish. The radius can then be read out from Figs. 2 and 3 and results in :formula: for :formula: and :formula: 0. These quantum skyrmion (SK) ground states occur not only for the fine-tuned parameters presented in Fig. 2 but in a wide range of intermediate values of the magnetic field. Furthermore, the emergence of individual skyrmions for small lattices is largely independent of the lattice geometry. While the effect of boundaries cannot be neglected for the small systems considered here, we verified that the size of an individual skyrmion is neither affected by the boundary conditions (see Fig. 2) nor the system diameter (see Fig. 8).

As we show in Fig. 2, for small magnetic fields, the sys- tem's ground state is a helical spin spiral (HS) state. This is characterized by a degenerate ground state, in which each pos- sible ground state features oscillations of the magnetization along a symmetry axis of the lattice. The large ground-state degeneracy makes the spin spiral phase notoriously difficult to simulate for tensor network states. In contrast, for large mag- netic fields, the system reaches a ferromagnetic state, where all spins are polarized parallel to the external magnetic field. The bulk of the field-polarized ferromagnet is devoid of entan-

FIG. 3. Components of the local polarization :formula: of the centered skyrmion ground state depicted in Fig. 2(e). glement and can thus be most efficiently approximated by an MPS. For parameters that result in SK ground states, DMRG reliably converges within a few dozen sweeps and yields ex- cellent MPS approximations with maximum truncation error :formula: even for small bond dimensions :formula:

We want to stress that the fine-tuned regime :formula: is not necessary to enter the skyrmion lattice phase. By in- creasing the ferromagnetic exchange coupling :formula: :formula: we obtain qualitatively similar results, which we present in Fig. 4. Note, however, that the corresponding system diameter for :formula: is dramatically increased compared to :formula: We attribute this to the fact that the skyrmion radius is determined by the ratio :formula:

To probe whether the spins of a skyrmion are entangled, a genuine quantum feature of many-body systems, we compute the entanglement entropy of a suitable bipartition of the sys- tem. The latter is defined as :formula: which can be understood as the von Neumann entropy of the reduced density matrix :formula: obtained by splitting the set of lattice sites :formula: into two disjoint sets :formula: and :formula: and performing the partial trace over subsystem :formula: For our purposes, it is sufficient to fix :formula: and :formula: as two patches that are symmetric about the central site (see Appendix B). We denote the entropy associated with this symmetric center-site partition choice as :formula: which is plotted in color in Fig. 4 and Fig. 9, panels (c) and (d).

MPS are constructed to target states of small entropy by truncating the reduced density matrix to a dimension :formula: which yields an upper bound for the entangle- ment entropy of an MPS state, :formula: a quantity on the order of :formula: for typical simulations. The bulk of FP states can be approximated by product states of :formula: particles aligned to the axis of the magnetic field, and for those states, one finds :formula: up to small finite-size corrections. In contrast, for systems hosting a single quantum skyrmion, we obtain val- ues for the entanglement entropy in the range :formula: which demonstrates the presence of significant entanglement in the :formula: quantum skyrmion and indicates that they can- not be expressed as a classical product state. Finally, in the HS phase, we find the strongest entanglement :formula: While we focus mainly on skyrmions with ferromagnetic exchange interaction :formula: we find strong signatures of skyrmions and skyrmion lattices for antiferromagnetic exchange :formula: 0) as well. However, this phase differs from the ferromag- netic skyrmions and skyrmion lattices, most apparently in the entanglement, which is significantly larger. We postpone a detailed investigation of quantum skyrmions and skyrmion lattices for antiferromagnetic exchange couplings to future work.

The von Neumann entropy targets quantum correlations between a bipartition of the system but does not provide local information about the entanglement between individual spin- :formula: pairs. To access the spatial distribution of entanglement, it is therefore more convenient to calculate the concurrence :formula: defined for two lattice sites at positions :formula: and :formula: For a generic state it can be expressed through the root of the spectrum of the non-Hermitian matrix :formula: where :formula: is the reduced density matrix of the two sites :formula: and :formula: and :formula: is a rotation of this reduced density matrix. The concurrence is constructed from the square roots :formula: (ordered in decreasing order) of the eigenvalues of :formula:

It is related to the entanglement of formation: for separable states :formula: vanishes, and it increases monotonically toward the limit :formula: for two maximally entangled spin-1/2's [58]. Using the concurrence, we obtain the space-resolved entan- glement distribution between spin pairs in the different phases and present its qualitative distribution by green links in Fig. 5. For HS states, we find the largest concurrences up to :formula: 0.16. Therefore, we use :formula: as a measure of reference to quantify the entanglement of the remaining ordered states. For the :formula: states (large magnetic field), we find almost vanishing entanglement in the bulk, indicating that the bulk spins are separable. Small nonzero values of :formula: occur at the boundary due to the finite system size and strong DMI. Fi- nally, for the quantum SK states (intermediate magnetic field), we find that the spins inside the skyrmion quasiparticle are only weakly entangled, but we find concurrences :formula: at the outer rim spins of the skyrmion, signaling significant en- tanglement of the quantum skyrmion with the field-polarized environment. Interestingly, both the helical state and quantum skyrmion show long-range concurrences between distant spin pairs beyond next-to-nearest neighbors.

quantum spin-1/2 Heisenberg models. We expect MPS to reliably capture the physics of the quantum skyrmion lattice phase because the external field polarizes the environment, and the resulting states carry no entanglement in the paramag- netic regions, but localized entanglement around the domain wall of the skyrmion.

We typically start with random MPS initial states of bond dimensions up to :formula: followed by sequential vari- ational optimizations ("sweeping") of two adjacent tensors (two-site DMRG). The two-site DMRG allows us to estimate the truncation error :formula: which we use in Fig. 10 to extrapolate toward results without numerical errors. To ensure that we display converged results only, we carefully monitor local spin expectation values and stop the simulation if changes in the observables become smaller than :formula: Since we use DMRG in two spatial dimensions, convergence to a spin spiral state may require many sweeps, on the order of 100-1000. To estimate the numerical error of our approximate wave functions, we perform linear extrapolations of the energy scaled against the truncation error [28] and the energy variance [43]. The outcomes of this extrapolation are presented in Fig. 10 and Table II. We want to stress that the MPS approximations corresponding to skyrmion and
field-polarized states easily reach convergence within a few dozen sweeps and follow the expected linear trend in the approximation errors :formula: and :formula: [26].

Changes in the local spin expectation values beyond :formula: 128 are invisible to the naked eye when displayed on the scales used in the main text such that a detailed error extrapolation is not needed. A word of caution is due in the case of helical spin spiral states: as we already explained in the main text, these states are difficult to simulate using MPS due to the large degeneracy of the ground-state manifold. This leads to some issues in reaching convergence (up to 1000 sweeps are needed) which for too small bond dimensions may even cause DMRG to get stuck in local energy minima corresponding to excited eigenstates. In the helical phase and for large lattices, MPS is thus not always reliably converging to approximations of the global ground state but converges under some circum- stances to low-lying excited states with less entanglement.

Before we can apply DMRG to the system at hand, the 2D lattice must be mapped to a 1D chain. The map from a 2D lattice to a 1D chain can be performed by a sequential numbering of the lattice nodes with major ordering along an arbitrary axis (zigzag order).
